Indicator.title: It is the metric representing the net income of the company/individual. It is calculated via subtracting the costs from the revenue of the company/individual.

The total expenses incurred in carrying out an organization's day-to-day activities, but not directly associated with production.Operating expenses include such things as payroll, sales commissions, employee benefits and pension contributions, transportation and travel, amortization and depreciation, rent, repairs, and taxes.
All expenses incurred by the company in the defined time period
Interest paid/payable on all types of deposits including deposits from banks and other institutions.
A reduction in the value of an asset over time, due in particular to wear and tear

Indicator.value: PAT Before ExtraOrdinary Items Annual Cr
Indicator.title: The net profit or loss for the year.All items of income and expense which are recognised in a year are included in the determination of the net profit or loss for the year.This includes extraordinary items and the effects of changes in accounting estimates.
Net profit or loss incurred for year after incorporating extraordinary income

Basic EPS - Basic earnings per share represents the amount of a company's profit or loss for a reporting period that is available to the shares of its common stock that are outstanding during the reporting period. It is a useful measure of performance for companies with simplified capital structures.
Annual Reports
The total interests earned on a loan
Income that is from activities not related to the regular sales of goods and services. Other revenue is generated in the course of non-regular business operations.
Cost incurred for employee salaries and employee related costs, including costs for provisions made to employees. Employees include directors of the company.

Indicator.value: Cost Of Power Purchased Annual Cr

Indicator.title: A minority interest, which is also referred to as noncontrolling interest (NCI), is ownership of less than 50% of a company's equity by an investor or another company. A proportional share of income shows up on the parent company's income statement attributable to the minority interest.

Indicator.title: Shareholders' funds is the balance sheet value of the shareholders' interest in a company. For company (as opposed to group) accounts it is simply all assets less all liabilities. For consolidated group accounts the the value of minority interests should also be excluded.
The noncurrent liability on the balance sheet of companies with a majority interest in a company, representing the proportion of its subsidiaries owned by minority shareholders.

Indicator.value: Total Non Current Liabilities Annual Cr

Indicator.title: This typically covers liabilities such as small accounts payable, and liabilities and prioisions that do not incur interest and are to be paidover a period longer than one year.

Indicator.value: Total Capital Plus Liabilities Annual Cr
Indicator.title: The summation of total capital and total liabilities of the company. Total capital refers to the sum of long-term debt and total shareholder equity; both of these items can be found on the company's balance sheet. Total liabilities refer to the aggregate of all debts an individual or company is liable for and can be easily calculated by summing all short-term and long-term liabilities, along with any off balance sheet liabilities that corporations may incur.

Line within the balance sheet which represents the monetary value forth long-term tangible pieces of property that a company owns and uses in the production of its income and is not expected to be consumed or converted into cash any sooner than at least one year's time

Indicator.value: Total Non Current Assets Annual Cr

Indicator.title: This represents a summation of the current and long-term assets of a company. As per the accounting equation, total assets = total liabilities + shareholder's equity

Indicator.value: Contingent Liabilities plus Commitments Annual Cr
Indicator.title: The line within the balance sheet wihich represents the potential liabilities that may occur, depending on the outcome of an uncertain future event. A contingent liability is recorded in the accounting records if the contingency is probable and the amount of the liability can be reasonably estimated.

Indicator.value: Bonus Equity Share Capital Annual Cr
Indicator.title: Capital from additional shares given by the company to the current shareholders without any additional cost, based upon the number of shares that a shareholder owns.

Indicator.value: Non Current Investments Unquoted BookValue Annual Cr
Current Investments Unquoted BookValue Annual Cr

Indicator.title: Invested money that, is not repaid to the investors in the normal course of business. It represents the capital staked by the owners through purchase of a company's common stock
The summation of the equity capital and preference capital of the company.
Reserves and surplus of the company

Indicator.value: Total Reserves Plus Surplus Annual Cr
Indicator.title: Total reserves and surplus of the company

Indicator.value: Capital Work In Progress Annual Cr
Long Term Loans Plus Advances Annual Cr
Other Non Current Assets Annual Cr
Cash Plus Cash Equivalents Annual Cr
Indicator.title: Cash and balances retained with the RBI.

Indicator.value: Short Term Loans Plus Advances Annual Cr

Indicator.value: Cash from Operating Activity Annual Cr
Indicator.title: Cash from operating activities usually refers to the net cash inflow reported in the first section of the statement of cash flows. Cash from operating activities focuses on the cash inflows and outflows from a company's main business activities of buying and selling merchandise, providing services, etc.

Indicator.value: Cash from Investing Activity Annual Cr
Indicator.title: Value on the cash flow statement representing the aggregate change in a company's cash position resulting from any gains (or losses) from investments in the financial markets and operating subsidiaries and changes resulting from amounts spent on investments in capital assets such as plant and equipment.

Indicator.value: Cash from Financing Annual Activity Cr
Indicator.title: The item on the cash flow statement accounting for the inflows and outflows of cash resulting from debt issuance and financing, the issuance of any new stock, dividend payments, and any repurchase of existing stock.
Interest paid/payable on all types of deposits including deposits from banks and other institutions.

Indicator.value: Cash Plus Cash Equivalent Begin Of Year Annual Cr
Indicator.title: The value of cash and cash equivalents of the company recorded at the beginning of the current fiscal year.

Indicator.value: Cash Plus Cash Equivalent End Of Year Annual Cr
Indicator.title: The value of cash and cash equivalents of the company recorded at the end of the current fiscal year.

Indicator.value: Book Value Per Share Annual Rs
Indicator.title: The book value per share not including the revaluation reserve. Book value per share is a measure used by owners of shares in a firm to determine the level of safety associated with each individual share after all debts are paid accordingly.

Return on assets. An indicator of how profitable a company is relative to its total assets. It provides an insight into how efficient a company's management is at using its assets to generate earnings and is displayed as a percentage. It is calculated using the formula ROA = Net Income / Total Assets

Return on equity. The amount of net income returned as a percentage of shareholders equity. It measures a corporation's profitability by revealing how much profit a company generates with the money shareholders have invested. It is calculated using the formula ROE = Net Income/Shareholder's Equity

Indicator.value: Total Debt to Total Equity Annual

Indicator.title: A measure of a company's total value, often used as a more comprehensive alternative to equity market capitalization. It is calculated using the formula EV = market value of common stock + market value of preferred equity + market value of debt + minority interest - cash and investments.

A valuation measure that compares the enterprise value (EV) of a company to the company's sales, giving investors a quantifiable metric of how much it costs to purchase the company's sales. It is calculated using the formula EV/Sales = (Market Capitalisation+Debt+Preferred Shares-Cash and Cash Equivalents)/Annual Sales

Price to Book Value Ratio.  A ratio which is used to compare a stock's market value to its book value. It is also known as price-equity ratio. It is calculated using the formula P/B Ratio = Market Price per Share / Book Value per Share

The proportion of earnings kept back in the business as retained earnings and is considered the opposite of Payout Ratio. It is calculated using the formula Retention Ratio = (Net Income - Dividends) / Net Income

A ratio which shows the percentage of each dollar/rupee invested in the stock that was earned by the company. Considered to be the inverse of the P/E ratio, it is used to to determine optimal asset allocations.

It is calculated using the formula ROA = Net Income / Total Assets

Return on equity. The amount of net income returned as a percentage of shareholders equity. It measures a corporation's profitability by revealing how much profit a company generates with the money shareholders have invested. It is calculated using the formula ROE = Net Income/Shareholder's Equity

Indicator.value: Total Debt to Total Equity Annual

Indicator.title: A measure of a company's total value, often used as a more comprehensive alternative to equity market capitalization. It is calculated using the formula EV = market value of common stock + market value of preferred equity + market value of debt + minority interest - cash and investments.

A valuation measure that compares the enterprise value (EV) of a company to the company's sales, giving investors a quantifiable metric of how much it costs to purchase the company's sales. It is calculated using the formula EV/Sales = (Market Capitalisation+Debt+Preferred Shares-Cash and Cash Equivalents)/Annual Sales

Price to Book Value Ratio.  A ratio which is used to compare a stock's market value to its book value. It is also known as price-equity ratio. It is calculated using the formula P/B Ratio = Market Price per Share / Book Value per Share

The proportion of earnings kept back in the business as retained earnings and is considered the opposite of Payout Ratio. It is calculated using the formula Retention Ratio = (Net Income - Dividends) / Net Income

A ratio which shows the percentage of each dollar/rupee invested in the stock that was earned by the company. Considered to be the inverse of the P/E ratio, it is used to to determine optimal asset allocations.
